lines.text: All we've been through, for nothing but an idea! Something that you cannot taste, smell, or feel; without substance, life, reality, memory.

I love them and they answer me with pain and torment. Be it sin or not sin, they have betrayed me in their hearts and that's far sin enough. I can see it in their eyes, I can feel it when they speak, and they must pay for it and be punished. I shall not be wounded and not return it in kind! I'm through with feeble hoping! I demand a man's vengeance!
[Calming down]

I'm a king, not a man. And a very civilized king. Could it possibly be civilized to destroy the thing I love? Could it possibly be civilized to love myself above all? What about their pain? And their torment? Did they ask for this calamity? Can passion be selected? Is there any doubt of their devotion to me? To our table?
Merlyn, make me a hawk! Let me fly away from here!
But even the thought, "I'm not thinking a thought" is thinking, isn't it?
Yes, and thinking is the sort of thing you should get into the habit of doing as often as possible.

[singing]
Don't let it be forgot / That once there was a spot / For one brief shining moment / That was known as Camelot!
Merlyn told me once, "Never be too disturbed if you don't understand what a woman is thinking. They don't do it very often".

[to Mordred]
Far more seasoned rascals than you have polished their souls, I advise you, get out the wax. Better to be rubbed clean than rubbed out.

[sardonically]
Mordred, I must remind you that I am a civilized man. With occasional lapses.
We must arrange for your knighthood.
No, sire! Invest me because of deeds, not words! Give me an order!
Now?
This moment! Is there some wrong I can right, some peril I can face, some quest I can undertake?
Well... actually... there's not much going on today. The Queen and some of her court have gone a-maying.
Gone... a-maying?
Well, it's a sort of... um... picnic? They pick flowers and chase young...
Picnic?
It's a custom we have here. This is England, you know. And this is the season for gathering flowers.
Knights? Gathering FLOWERS?
Well, SOMEONE has to do it!
I like my women married, my willpower weak, my wine strong, and my saints fallen.
What's the best thing for being sad?
The best thing for being sad is to learn something.
Proposition. It is far better to be alive than dead.
Proposition. Right or wrong. They have the might. So, right or wrong. They're always right. That's wrong. Right?
Excuse a, ah - me. But do you not have any, ah, activities? Any, ah, hobbies? Any, ah, chambering de coucher?
No, Pellinore.

[to King Arthur]
There, you see. You see. Now, why can't he be like the other chaps instead of like himself? Why can't he come home in the evening and hang up his shield and do something that he can be ashamed of! Hmmm? He sure is French.

Proposition. If I could choose from every woman who breathes on this earth, the face I would most love, the smile, the touch, the heart, the voice, the laugh, the soul, itself, every detail and feature to the last strand of the hair, they would all be Ginny's.
Proposition. If I could choose from every man who breathes on this earth, a man for my brother, a man for my son, and a man for my friend, it would all be Lance.
By God, I shall be a king. This is the time of King Arthur. When we shall - reach for the stars! This is the time of King Arthur when violence is not strength and compassion is not weakness!
I can't quite remember all that Merlyn taught me, but I do remember this. That happiness is a virtue. No one can be happy and wicked. Triumphant, perhaps, but not happy.
Arthur, who was that?
One of what we all are, Pelli! Less than a drop in the great blue motion of the sunlit sea. But, it seems, that some of the drops - Sparkle, Pelli! Some of them doooooo - Sparkle!

[singing]
In short, there's simply not / a more congenial spot / for happily ever aftering than here in Camelot.
Must we talk about Mordred? This is the first time in a month that he's not coming to dinner and not having him makes it seem like a party!
Dap, you are older than I. You know this Earth better than I. I only fell upon it a few hours ago.
What are you talking about?
Guinevere!
Arise, Sir Lancelot.
If the king grants you clemency, you shall be banished. If not, you hang.
Clemency is granted.
Ginny, I - I love you. God forgive me, but I do.
Then God forgive us both, Lance.

[King Arthur runs into the room]
Ginny, Ginny! Oh, what a glorious day!
The next time you traffic with me, remember... you challenge the right hand of King Arthur!
I *am* King Arthur!
What? You... are the king?
Almost the *late* king...

[singing offscreen]
Guinevere, Guinevere / In that dim, mournful year / Saw the men she held so dear / Go to war for Guinevere

[singing offscreen]
Guinevere, Guinevere / Oh, they found Guinevere / In the dying candle's gleam / Came the sundown of a dream
[first lines]
The rules of battle are not for Lancelot Du Lac, Your Majesty! Let us attack now while they sleep!

[firmly]
We will attack when I give the command - at dawn.
[the knight leaves, and Arthur begins to talk to himself]
Oh, Merlyn, Merlyn, why is Ginny in that castle, behind walls I cannot enter? How did I blunder into this agonizing absurdity? Where did I stumble? How did I go wrong? Should I not have loved her?
[sighs]
Then I should not have been born! Oh, Merlyn, I haven't got much time. Within an inch of sunlight, the arrows begin to fly. If I am to die in battle, please, please do not let me die bewildered!

[voice only, far off in the distance]
Think back, Arthur! Think back!
Was there ever a more inconvenient marriage of convenience? Here am I, at the golden age of seductibility and is my fate sealed with a kiss? Is it? No. Sealed with a seal.
It's the most ferocious, savage, terrifying forest I've ever seen. I simply adore it.
Does your ladyship not realize that this forest is crawling with outlaws and dragons?
Oh, Clari, do you think there's any chance that we can see one?
Don't say it, ma'am.
It would be marvelous.
You could be my protector! You think of it? You could defend me all over the world in France and England, Mongolia. Scotland.

Ginny, Ginny, suppose we create a new order of chivalry? A new order where might is only used for right! To improve instead of to destroy. Look, we'll invite all the knights, all the kings of all the kingdoms, to lay down there arms to come and join us. Oh yes, Ginny. I will take one of the large rooms in the castle, put a table in it, and all the knights will gather at it.
And do what?
Talk across it. Debate. Make laws. Plan improvements!
But, Arthur, do you think all the knights will ever want to? To do such a ridiculously peaceful thing?

We'll make it a great honor. Very fashionable! Everyone will want to join! Only now, the knights will whack only for good. Might for right. Might for right. Might - for - right. That's it, Ginny. Might. No, not might is right. Might - For - Right!
It's very original.
Yes. Yes-Yes. And civilized, Ginny.
Arthur, it will have to be an awfully large table. Won't there be jealousy? All the knights will be claiming superiority and want to sit at the head.
We'll make it - a round table. So, there is no head.
My strength, from purity.
Well, that's a unique recipe.
He is a unique man, your majesty.
I have stumbled on my future. I-I-I've done - the right thing!
Did you ever doubt it, your majesty?
Oh, of course. Of course. Only fools never doubt.
It's all his fault, you know. Emperor Charlemagne, there. He has no activities. That's his trouble. No secular pleasures.
Well, this is appalling Ginny! It will seem to the court that you are championing his defeat!
We don't know if he'll be defeated. He knocked you unconscious. You woke up his bosom friend. Perhaps he'll knock them out too and they'll all take a house by the sea together.
Ginny, I realize he's having a difficult time adjusting. He's a stranger! He's not even English. He's French!
Well, he suffers in translation.
I'm too young and too old. Too old not to know that fears can be imaginary and too young not to be tormented by them.
There's a poison in this Court that will kill us all.

I know, I know what I should do. Leave and never come back. Today. This minute. But to leave so abruptly, would seem a confession. No. Better in a week or two or a month. How can I go, Ginny? Look at you.
I want you to go, Lance.
Ginny, Ginny.

No, I do. I don't worry about the future, we have none. But, if anything happened to the past, any more shame and any more guilt, could make a ruin of it. The past is all I have. The past is all I have.
Arthur, the uglier the truth, the truer the friend that tells you.
Pelli, call the guard and have this pompous young ass thrown out.
Learn. Learn - why the world wags and what wags it!
How could I learn if I couldn't think? And I couldn't think; so, I couldn't learn. But, even to think the thought, I thought. But, even the thought, I'm not thinking a thought, is thinking, isn't it?

Yes! And thinking, boy, is something you should definitely get into the habit of making use of, as often as possible. Thinking helps in everything. Everything but love, that is. Love is a sort of seventh day, so thinking can rest.
There are times when the only vacation spot in the world - is the past.
